site.title: Machine Learning in Chemical Physics @ Princeton
site.tagline: This group is for exploring machine learning in chemical physics, we're open to all!

hero.title: Machine Learning in Chemical Physics @ Princeton
hero.subtitle: Seasonal deep-dives into how molecular simulations, experiments, theory, and machine learning enable new discoveries in chemistry and physics. Open to all! Feel free to join, use our resources, or present work you're excited about. For talks--I (Jacob) am a strong believer in the power of free food, as such we will always look to provide some sort of snack for the in-person sessions. We will also hold online sessions in conjunction so anyone, anywhere can join in on the discussions!

hero.title: About Machine Learning in Chemical Physics @ Princeton
hero.subtitle: Each season curates a focused theme with slide decks, key references, and discussion points/presentations maintained for future readers. If you're interested in joining us as a speaker or as a participant, please reach out to the organizers!

body: We are an open group of graduate students, postdocs, faculty, and friends from the surrounding community who study topics in chemical physics. Every few months we choose a topic and learn about it, bringing each other up to speed and exploring new literature.

organizers.name: Jacob Votava
organizers.bio: Third year PhD candidate in the Webb and Davidson groups researching conformational effects in liquid crystals and polymers using classical simulations, quantum chemical calculations, and machine learning methods.

organizers.name: Moritz Obenauer
organizers.bio: Second year PhD student in the Jacobs group working on the dynamics of self-assembly processes of chemically driven systems.

advisors.name: Mike Webb
advisors.bio: Professor Webb's group broadly uses theory and simulation to characterize, understand, and guide the design of novel soft materials for health and sustainability applications.

advisors.name: Will Jacobs
advisors.bio: Professor Jacobs' group focuses on coarse-grained and machine-learned models to understand phase-separation and self-assembly in biomolecular systems in and out of equilibrium.

advisors.name: Andrew Rosen
advisors.bio: Professor Rosen's group applies electronic structure calculations and machine learning to guide the discovery of solid-state materials that can address global challenges in energy and sustainability.

advisors.name: Emily Davidson
advisors.bio: Professor Davidson's group focuses on using experimental chemistry and physics to understand hierarchical materials with applications in sustainability and additive manufacturing.

sponsors.name: (AI²) AI for Accelerating Invention, Princeton University

seasons.title: Season 1: Machine-Learned Interatomic Potentials
seasons.description: Machine learned interatomic potentials, from Behler-Parinello to foundation models and coarse-graining.

hero.title: Machine-Learned Interatomic Potentials
hero.subtitle: We explore machine learned potentials, starting from Parinello's classic architecture and working our way up to modern foundation models!
hero.credit: image credit: Friederich, Pascal, et al. "Machine-learned potentials for next-generation matter simulations." Nature Materials 20.6 (2021): 750-761.

seasons.title: Generative Models in Chemical Physics
seasons.description: Spring 2026 lineup on generative models in materials design and discovery.

hero.title: Generative Models in Chemical Physics
hero.subtitle: A spring 2026 series exploring generative models (diffusion models, transformers, VAEs. flow matching) and their applications in chemical physics—with an external keynote speaker to finish us off (TBA).
hero.imageAlt: Generative models for chemical physics illustration
hero.credit: image credit: Tiwary, Pratyush, et al. "Generative AI for computational chemistry: A roadmap to predicting emergent phenomena." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 122.41 (2025): e2415655121.
